business_hypothesis: Higher values of campaign_sub_metric_2 are associated with higher conversion rates.
science_hypothesis: A positive monotonic association exists (Spearman rho ≥ 0.40) between campaign_sub_metric_2 and conversion_rate, robust to controls for top_funnel_spend_usd and date effects.
null_case: No monotonic relationship: Spearman rho ∈ [-0.10, 0.10] or p > 0.05, and partial Spearman controlling for spend has rho ≈ 0.

validation_methods.execution_plan: Compute Spearman rho between campaign_sub_metric_2 and conversion_rate and fit a monotonic spline, then compute a partial Spearman controlling for top_funnel_spend_usd and date fixed effects. Pass if Spearman rho ≥ 0.40 and partial rho ≥ 0.30 with p < 0.05 and the spline shows a non-decreasing slope across the central 80% of campaign_sub_metric_2 values.

Bin campaign_sub_metric_2 into quintiles, compute mean conversion_rate per quintile, and run a Cochran-Armitage trend test or linear regression on quintile medians to detect monotonic trend. Pass if conversion_rate increases monotonically across quintiles with trend test p < 0.05 and the relative increase top vs bottom quintile ≥ 10%.

Bootstrap the paired samples 10,000 times to generate a distribution of Spearman rho and compute 95% and 99% confidence intervals while checking stability across random seeds and subsamples. Pass if the 95% CI lower bound ≥ 0.20, the 99% CI lower bound ≥ 0.10, and the bootstrap stability (fraction of bootstraps with rho > 0) ≥ 0.85.
